_prev_prog_3.Description:
The Dot Foods, Inc. facility uses three independent ammonia systems (Engine Room #1& Engineine Room #2, Engine Room #3, and Engine Room #4).  All items in this prevention program apply to all three systems with the following exceptions:
-  The dates of the PHA, which are 10/26/2004 - 10/28/2004 for Engine Room # 1 & #2, 4/3/2006 - 4/4/2006 for Engine Room #3, and 7/16/2007-7/19/2007 for Engine Room #4.
-  For item 7.4h, there was a reduction in chemical inventory for Engine Room #4 and an increase in chemical inventory in Engine Room #3.  There were no changes made for Engine Room #1 & #2.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

DOT Foods, Inc., founded in 1960, is the largest food redistributor in the United States serving distributors coast to coast on a daily basis. Headquartered in Mt. Sterling, Illinois, DOT is a family owned business that has grown from a single station wagon driven by the founder, Robert Tracy, to a fleet of over 400 multi-temp tractor trailers. This growth is in large part due to the customer driven attitude that is exhibited by all the members of the DOT team.  As stated on their website, ?DOT Foods will continue to be driven by the values of integrity, growth, profit, and customer satisfaction, with emphasis on innovation and employee welfare.?

DOT Foods, Inc., located in Mt. Sterling, Illinois, provides refrigeration for packaging frozen food as well as warehousing and distribution of food and related products and services. DOT Foods, Inc.?s senior management is not only committed to offer superior service, but also maintains a safety and environmental program to promote a safe environment for all its employees and the surrounding communities. DOT Foods, Inc. administers safety and environmental policies at the facility to ensure compliance with OSHA?s Process Safety Management (PSM) and EPA?s Risk Management Program (RMP). These programs include forklift safety, hazard communications, lockout/tagout, employee safety manuals, manufacturers? documentation, and the Emergency Response Plan.

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

DOT Foods, Inc. is located at 1 Dot Way in Mt. Sterling, Illinois.  The facility is approximately 0.4 mile south of Interstate 24 and approximately 0.08 mile (410 feet) west of Interstate 99.  The area surrounding the facility is rural with a mixture of light business and residential areas. 

The refrigeration systems were designed and constructed in accordance with all applicable federal, state, and local regulations.

The primary business of DOT Foods, Inc. ? Mt. Sterling

is the packaging of frozen foods.  In order to conduct operations, the facility currently uses a maximum of 71,725 pounds of ammonia in its three independent ammonia refrigeration systems.  The three ammonia refrigeration systems are located in Engine Room #1 & #2, Engine Room #3, and Engine Room #4, each containing the following charge of ammonia: 38,600 pounds, 14,325 pounds, and 18,800 pounds, respectively.  The ammonia refrigeration systems use ammonia for dock operations, warehouse cold storage, and freezer storage.  The majority of the system is located in the machine room including vessels and compressors.  The condensers are mounted on the machine room roof and all of the evaporators are located in their respective cold storage rooms/areas.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The DOT Foods, Inc. facility was designed and constructed in accordance with the Uniform Mechanical Code which specifically outlines requirements for the safe operation of ammonia refrigeration systems.  These safety features include ammonia sensors in the machine rooms as well as sensors in selected cold storage areas, and automatic shut down systems.  In addition, the majority of the ammonia is maintained inside the engine room or on the engine rooms roof (condensers).

There are ammonia and temperature sensors placed in the engine rooms (#1 & #2, #3, and #4), freezer, cooler, and dock areas.  In the event of ammonia detection, a facility alarm sounds and a visible alarm is triggered.

In addition to the Uniform Mechanical Code, the facility will operate in accordance with the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR) guidelines, in particular, the IIAR Bulletin 110, "Startup, Inspection, and Maintenance of Ammonia Refrigeration Systems."

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

An investigation into the DOT Foods, Inc. ? Mt. Sterling facility?s accident history revealed that there have been no reportable ammonia releases (> 100 pounds) ov

er the past five years (March 2004 ? March 2009).  In addition, there have been no injuries resulting from an ammonia release.  

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

DOT Foods, Inc. has an emergency response plan in effect at the facility.   The Emergency Response Plan (Plan) is detailed in the Emergency Planning and Response section of the PSM document, which is maintained at the facility. This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives:

? To save lives.
? To minimize and avoid injuries.
? To protect the environment.
? To minimize property damage.

The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  The facility maintains a safety committee (a trained Emergency Response team) whose members are designated emergency coordinators for the facility who will respond to minor leaks.  The emergency response team is trained to call 9-1-1 in an event of an ammonia release.  The 9-1-1 operator will contact the Mt. Sterling Fire Department.  

Employees within the building are evacuated to a point upwind of the facility or shelter in place.  Evacuation drills are performed annually.  This Plan will be reviewed and updated at least once per year to ensure compliance with the PSM and RMP regulations, as well as to incorporate facility changes due to the renovation of the facility.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) performed in 10/26/2004-10/28/2004 for Engine Room #1 & #2, 4/3/2006-4/4/2006 for Engine Room #3, and 7/16/2007-7/19/2007 for Engine Room #4, generated mitigation measures (recommendations) to improve safety at the DOT Foods, Inc. facility located at 1 Dot Way, Mt. Sterling, Illinois.  The scheduled completion date of all changes resulting from the PHA's is December 31, 2009.  In the meantime, DOT Foods, Inc. safety committee has completed

several items, including the recommendations, in a continual effort to provide a safe work environment for their employees. These changes include the following items:

1. Continue to train all employees in Process Safety Management and the facility Safety Plan/Programs.

2. Continue to have employee involvement in Safety Plan Development.

3. Continue employee involvement through safety team participation.

4. Continue internal and external safety audits/inspections and implement changes as needed.
